SAIL

Software & Application Innovation Lab

The Software & Application Innovation Lab (SAIL) at Boston University’s Hariri Institute for Computing provides professional software consulting, design, and development capacity to support research efforts across Boston University that involve or require custom software, computational, and data-centric components. SAIL is committed to promoting innovation within the research community and will learn new technologies and techniques as determined by the needs of any given project.

Projects

Dietary Approaches to Stopping Hypertension (DASH) for Health App

SAIL worked with BU Medical Campus IT to design and build a cross-platform mobile application for Devin Mann, Associate Professor of Medicine at BU and an Associate Chief Medical Information Officer at Boston Medical Center. The app enables users to track their food consumption by tapping tiles that correspond to the eight components of a healthy diet. The app connects via Bluetooth to a blood pressure monitor, scale, and pedometer; it also allows users to connect with health coaches through a messaging function. This work demonstrates how a resource like SAIL can enable a successful and sustained mobile health research ecosystem at BU.

Contributors:
Frederick Jansen Software Engineer

Natural Language Processing for Political Science

SAIL staff and student developers are helping Cathie Jo Martin, Professor of Political Science at Boston University, to collect natural language data sets consisting of Danish and British fiction literature from third party sources and services, and to identify and apply appropriate machine learning techniques to these corpora. This work supports Prof. Martin’s goal of understanding deep cultural differences in views toward education as they can be observed in coming-of-age novels in Britain and Denmark. This work represents a part of a broader effort to advance the digital humanities by making computational techniques more accessible to researchers in the social sciences.

Contributors:
Ben Getchell Software Engineer Intern
Frederick Jansen Software Engineer

Secure Compensation Analytics for the City of Boston

In support of the Boston Women’s Workforce Council and its mission to advance salary equity among Boston employers as part of the 100% Talent Compact, SAIL staff and student developers built a secure multi-party computation web application that allows statistical data pertaining to compensation levels across genders and demographics to be collected from about 70 participating employer organizations, such as State Street Corporation and Putnam Investments, without requiring any organization to reveal its confidential data. This platform is unique in that it allows real-world organizations to use what is still largely studied as a theoretical technique, enabling analyses that would have been otherwise impossible to do while preserving the confidentiality of the participants.

Contributors:
Eric Dunton Software Engineer Intern, CAS ‘15
Kyle Holzinger Software Engineer Intern, CAS ’15
Frederick Jansen Software Engineer

Contact Us

If you think SAIL may be able to help you achieve your research objectives or would like to discuss what resources are available, please fill out a request form or contact Andrei Lapets (lapets@bu.edu), Director of Research Development, directly. If you are seeking other forms of support for your research (including seed funding), you may also want to review the Hariri Research Award program.

SAIL is seeking professional software engineers and student software engineer interns. Please contact Andrei Lapets (lapets@bu.edu) or Frederick Jansen (fjansen@bu.edu) if you are interested applying for a position.

Andrei Lapets

Andrei Lapets, Director of Research Development, Computer Science lecturer and formerly an Institute Postdoctoral Fellow, develops and manages strategic research initiatives. He provides support for faculty, researchers, and students who are planning, proposing, or engaging in interdisciplinary or collaborative research efforts. Andrei also guides the Hariri Research Award program and oversees the Software and Application Innovation Lab (SAIL).

lapets@bu.edu

Frederick Jansen

Frederick Jansen, Software Engineer, is responsible for the design and development of software in support of computational research and is part of the Software and Application Innovation Lab (SAIL).

fjansen@bu.edu
